text: [Applause]
Nathan welcome thank you um so Jay
talked about some of the exciting things
that are going on and you're going to
pick up the ball maybe run in slightly
different directions maybe carry it
further down the field what what are
your hopes and aspir ations uh about
this new job not what are you going to
do exactly but what do what do what do
you hope to accomplish I I I just uh
first and foremost have to say that uh
being in a room where one of the first
opportunities I get is to be with uh the
extraordinary alumni of the school from
now I guess the class uh 55 is the one
that we have that is um here and uh just
the great legacy that I have now the
responsibility of continuing is the
first thing that I that I'm really
excited to continue I think the school
has a great tradition here we are
entering the second century of our
existence uh as Jay said uh it's a time
in which even though the last few years
have felt very difficult I actually feel
enormously optimistic I think the world
needs a lot more of what we do uh as a
school whose mission is to educate
leaders who make a difference in the
world just think about all we can do the
world's globalizing there's uh
opportunities to bring more and more
people in all parts of the world into
the circle of prosperity that has been
enjoyed historically in the west uh
there is a need to create jobs in the
United States there are extraordinarily
important problems in healthcare uh in
environmental sustainability in
reshaping Capital markets so everywhere
I look I think there's actually an
extraordinary opportunity for business
to contribute to do what it has
historically done uh which is to
contribute to the prosperity of society
in profoundly important ways uh and the
har business school which has been at
the center of that has a great role to
play uh
We've produced for society all over the
world including in the United States but
certainly not just in the United States
in Europe in Asia in Africa leaders who
make a real difference and now is the
time for us to step up our game and do
more of that so I feel I'm very blessed
to be uh Dean at a time when uh the
demand for leadership in the world in
fact is uh more than it's ever been uh
and we have to be the school that
provides the leaders uh that will go out
and and do the things that Society needs
all over the world to solve the problems
that are so pressing and so daunting for
us today but which can only be solved in
some ways through business uh in
partnership with other other
institutions in the world so I I feel
this is a remarkable time in the school
thanks to Jay's great leadership while
uh other institutions are a little
worried still about their financial
affairs uh we're in a very strong place
as a school uh so I think that thanks to
him I've I've inherited a platform where
our opportunity to uh innovate our
opportunity to invest our opportunity to
go forward boldly is better than it's
ever been and for that I'm very grateful
to uh to Jay and the extraordinary Deans
that have come before
me nothing uh as we think about
leadership you know it's a word that's
band-aided about a great deal and about
which uh people probably have differing
opinions as to its uh definition how do
what is leadership to you and how can we
develop leaders how should we think
about that as a educational process and
as a
responsibility so I've always uh thought
of uh leaders as people who can work
with a group of other people to
accomplish collectively remarkable
things that no one individual could have
done alone and being the Catalyst that
enables another group of people to
collectively create value that no one
individual could have created alone is
really at the heart of what leadership
is uh it's something that the school
school has uh long committed itself to
teaching it certainly requires people to
understand the basics the kind of
fundamentals the principles of
management and Leadership if you will uh
all the way from knowing how to make
sure that you run a tight budget you
know how to do Capital asset pricing uh
you know the four Ps of management so
there's certainly a need to understand
the principles of management that allow
you to Be an Effective leader but then
you have to put those principles into
practice and this is where I think the
schools tradition of the case method uh
which really forces you to to understand
how business problems really present
themselves in the real world uh has been
a very important part but I think we
need to do more in terms of helping
leaders really learn even while they're
here how to put what they're learning
into practice but the ultimate thing
that I think leaders are about is you
know what's the purpose of your
leadership why are you doing this in
what ways do you feel like you make a
difference in the world I think that's a
question that in recent times we have we
may not have asked as rigorously as we
should it's a question that I think we
need to ask our students to think about
more carefully
so that they can go out in the world and
and be these agents of change that
Society expects them to be
